#T_RL=webanno.custom.Coref|type|BT_webanno.custom.Referent
#Text=THE BURGLARS

#Text=It was much too fine a night to think of going to bed at once , and so , although the witching hour of nine P.M. had struck , Edward and I were still leaning out of the open window in our nightshirts , watching the play of the cedar-branch shadows on the moonlit lawn , and planning schemes of fresh devilry for the sunshiny morrow .

#Text=From below , strains of the jocund piano declared that the Olympians were enjoying themselves in their listless , impotent way ; for the new curate had been bidden to dinner that night , and was at the moment unclerically proclaiming to all the world that he feared no foe .

#Text=His discordant vociferations doubtless started a train of thought in Edward 's mind , for the youth presently remarked , a propos of nothing that had been said before , “ I believe the new curate 's rather gone on Aunt Maria . ”
#Text=I scouted the notion .
#Text=“ Why , she 's quite old , ” I said . ( She must have seen some five-and-twenty summers . )
#Text=“ Of course she is , ” replied Edward , scornfully .
#Text=“ It 's not her , it 's her money he 's after , you bet ! ”
#Text=“ Did n't know she had any money , ” I observed timidly .
#Text=“ Sure to have , ” said my brother , with confidence .
#Text=“ Heaps and heaps . ”

#Text=Silence ensued , both our minds being busy with the new situation thus presented , -- mine , in wonderment at this flaw that so often declared itself in enviable natures of fullest endowment , -- in a grown-up man and a good cricketer , for instance , even as this curate ; Edward 's ( apparently ) , in the consideration of how such a state of things , supposing it existed , could be best turned to his own advantage .
#Text=“ Bobby Ferris told me , ” began Edward in due course , “ that there was a fellow spooning his sister once -- ”
#Text=“ What 's spooning ? ” I asked meekly .
#Text=“ Oh , I dunno , ” said Edward , indifferently .
#Text=“ It's -- it's -- it 's just a thing they do , you know .
#Text=And he used to carry notes and messages and things between ' em , and he got a shilling almost every time . ”
#Text=“ What , from each of ' em ? ” I innocently inquired .
#Text=Edward looked at me with scornful pity .
#Text=“ Girls never have any money , ” he briefly explained .
#Text=“ But she did his exercises and got him out of rows , and told stories for him when he needed it -- and much better ones than he could have made up for himself .
#Text=Girls are useful in some ways .
#Text=So he was living in clover , when unfortunately they went and quarrelled about something . ”
#Text=“ Do n't see what that 's got to do with it , ” I said .
#Text=“ Nor do n't I , ” rejoined Edward .
#Text=“ But anyhow the notes and things stopped , and so did the shillings .
#Text=Bobby was fairly cornered , for he had bought two ferrets on tick , and promised to pay a shilling a week , thinking the shillings were going on for ever , the silly young ass .

#Text=So when the week was up , and he was being dunned for the shilling , he went off to the fellow and said , ' Your broken-hearted Bella implores you to meet her at sundown , -- by the hollow oak , as of old , be it only for a moment .
#Text=Do not fail ! '
#Text=He got all that out of some rotten book , of course .
#Text=The fellow looked puzzled and said , --
#Text=“ ' What hollow oak ?
#Text=I do n't know any hollow oak .
#Text='

#Text=“ ' Perhaps it was the Royal Oak ? ' said Bobby promptly , ' cos he saw he had made a slip , through trusting too much to the rotten book ; but this did n't seem to make the fellow any happier . ”
#Text=“ Should think not , ” I said , “ the Royal Oak 's an awful low sort of pub . ”
#Text=“ I know , ” said Edward .
#Text=“ Well , at last the fellow said , ' I think I know what she means : the hollow tree in your father 's paddock .
#Text=It happens to be an elm , but she would n't know the difference .
#Text=All right : say I 'll be there . '
#Text=Bobby hung about a bit , for he had n't got his money . '
#Text=She was crying awfully , ' he said .
#Text=Then he got his shilling . ”
#Text=“ And was n't the fellow riled , ” I inquired , “ when he got to the place and found nothing ? ”
#Text=“ He found Bobby , ” said Edward , indignantly .
#Text=“ Young Ferris was a gentleman , every inch of him .
#Text=He brought the fellow another message from Bella : ' I dare not leave the house .
#Text=My cruel parents immure me closely If you only knew what I suffer .
#Text=Your broken-hearted Bella . '
#Text=Out of the same rotten book .
#Text=This made the fellow a little suspicious , ' cos it was the old Ferrises who had been keen about the thing all through : the fellow , you see , had tin . ”
#Text=“ But what 's that got to -- ” I began again .
#Text=“ Oh , I dunno , ” said Edward , impatiently .
#Text=“ I 'm telling you just what Bobby told me .
#Text=He got suspicious , anyhow , but he could n't exactly call Bella 's brother a liar , so Bobby escaped for the time .
#Text=But when he was in a hole next week , over a stiff French exercise , and tried the same sort of game on his sister , she was too sharp for him , and he got caught out .
#Text=Somehow women seem more mistrustful than men .
#Text=They 're so beastly suspicious by nature , you know . ”
#Text=“ I know , ” said I. “ But did the two -- the fellow and the sister -- make it up afterwards ? ”

#Text=“ I do n't remember about that , ” replied Edward , indifferently ; “ but Bobby got packed off to school a whole year earlier than his people meant to send him , -- which was just what he wanted .
#Text=So you see it all came right in the end ! ”
